planets.name: Mercury
planets.curiosity: The smallest planet in our solar system and closest to the Sun - is only slightly larger than Earth's Moon. Mercury is the fastest planet, zipping around the Sun every 88 Earth days

planets.name: Venus
planets.curiosity: Venus spins slowly in the opposite direction from most planets. A thick atmosphere traps heat in a runaway greenhouse effect, making it the hottest planet in our solar system.

planets.name: Earth
planets.curiosity: Earth-our home planet--is the only place we know of so far that's inhabited by living things. It's also the only planet in our solar system with liquid water on the surface.

planets.name: Mars
planets.curiosity: Mars is a dusty, cold, desert world with a very thin atmosphere. There is strong evidence Mars was - billions of years ago - wetter and warmer, with a thicker atmosphere.

planets.name: Jupiter
planets.curiosity: Jupiter is more than twice as massive than the other planets of our solar system combined. The giant planet's Great Red spot is a centuries-old storm bigger than Earth.

planets.name: Saturn
planets.curiosity: Adorned with a dazzling, complex system of icy rings, Saturn is unique in our solar system. The other giant planets have rings, but none are as spectacular as Saturn's.

planets.name: Uranus
planets.curiosity: Uranus-seventh planet from the Sun-rotates at a nearly 90-degree angle from the plane of its orbit. This unique tilt makes Uranus appear to spin on its side.

planets.name: Neptune
planets.curiosity: Neptune-the eighth and most distant major planet orbiting our Sun- is dark, cold and whipped by supersonic winds. It was the first planet located through mathematical calculations.
